_prev_prog_3.MD_OtherType: Two area video survellance cameras that are available at any time, day or night, by dial-up connection to Houston Control.
_prev_prog_3.Description: Facility is a propane loading facility for transport trucks.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Environmental Protection Agency Risk Management Plan
Enterprise Mankato Terminal & Storage
Risk Management Plan (RMP)
Executive Summary

The Enterprise Mankato Terminal and Storage is a propane storage and terminal facility owned by Enterprise Terminal & Storage, LLC, a wholly owned subsidiary of Mapletree, LLC and operated by Enterprise Products Operating, LLC.

At the Enterprise Mankato Terminal and Storage, we are committed to operating and maintaining all of our processes (especially those using hazardous substances) in a safe and responsible manner.  We use a combination of accidental release prevention programs and emergency response planning programs to help ensure the safety of our employees and the public, as well as protection of the environment.  This document provides a brief overview of the comprehensive risk management activities that we have designed and implemented, including:

* A description of our facility and use of substances required by EPA's RMP regulation and the processes involved
* A summary of results from our assessment of the potential offsite consequences from accidental chemical releases
* Emergency Response Programs
* General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps
* A five-year accident history for accidental releases of chemicals at the Mankato Terminal that are regulated by EPA?s RMP rule.  

Facility Description

The Mankato facility is a pipeline, storage and transport truck loading facility.  The pipeline system is a liquefied petroleum gas (LPG) pipeline system which is regulated by the Department of Transportation.  The propane storage and  loading facilities are regulated by Federal OSHA 29 CFR 1910.119 and 40 CFR Part 68.  We have entered the facility as an RMP Program Level 3 facility.

The Mankato Terminal has two pipelines that are routed through the facility and are regulated by the Department of Transportation.  These two pipelines are a part of a mix product line (natural gasoline,

naphtha, normal butane, iso-butane and propane) and a dedicated propane line   In addition, the facility receives propane from the pipeline to four 90,000 gallon capacity storage tanks.  These tanks are used for distribution to the truck transport loading docks which also has capabilities to stench the propane for retail sales companies.  The previously mentioned propane storage tanks are administratively controlled to hold and not exceed a maximum volume of 80% of each tank's full capacity..

In our facility we use the following chemicals that the EPA has identified as having the potential to cause significant offsite consequence in the event of a substantial accidental release:

Toxics

There are no listed toxic substances handled by the Enterprise Mankato Terminal and Storage facility..

Flammables

Propane is a finished product which can be delivered into four storage tanks via the dedicated propane pipeline, or the mixed product pipeline.  This material is routed from these tanks to the truck transport loading docks for whole sale to propane retailers.

A small quantity of Ethyl Mercaptan is used to stench the propane at the truck transport docks.

Key Offsite Consequence Analysis Scenarios

The EPA's RMP rule requires that we provide information about the worst-case scenarios(s) and alternative release scenario(s) for our facility.  The following are brief summaries of these scenarios, including information about the key administrative controls and mitigation measures to limit the exposure distances for each scenario.

Worst Case Release Scenario ? Regulated Toxic Chemical

There are no toxic chemicals handled by Mankato Terminal.

Alternate Release Scenario(s) ? Regulated Toxic Chemical

There are no toxic chemicals handled by Mankato Terminal. 

Worse Case Scenario ? Regulated Flammable Chemicals

This simulation involves the rupture or failure of the propane storage tanks resulting in a simulated vapor cloud explosion.  Inventory from all four tanks are sim

ulated due to the proximity of the tanks relative to mitigation to the simulation.  This scenario would not be mitigated due to the type of scenario modeled.  All emergency response and early warning to the employees and the community would be exercised immediately if this were to occur.  The quantity and endpoint of the simulation and the specifics of the simulation are available in the specified reporting of the Risk Management Plan

Alternate Case Scenario ? Regulated Flammable Chemicals

The alternate release scenario is a simulated rupture of the supply pipe to the loading docks resulting in a ten minute release and simulated vapor cloud explosion.  This scenario assumed the pump continued to operate at a rate of approximately 500 gallons per minutes (gpm) for 10 minutes after the line break.  The simulation calculated that 30,500 pounds of material were released in the assumed time frame.  Mitigation measures were taken into account when selecting the alternative release scenario.  This consisted of reviewing the use of relief valves, check valves, manual shutoff valves, automatic shutoffs, startup and operating procedures, grounding equipment, and excess flow devices.  This scenario would be mitigated due to the type of scenario modeled.  Activation of the Emergency Shutdown Devices would isolate the source of the material and secure the facility.  All emergency response and early warning to the employees and the community would be exercised immediately if this were to occur.  The quantity and endpoint of the simulation is contained in the data elements.

We are using this information to help us ensure that our emergency response plan and the community emergency response plan address all reasonable contingency cases.

Emergency Response Program

Enterprise maintains an integrated contingency plan, which consolidates all of the various federal, state, and local regulatory requirements for emergency response planning and reporting.  The program provides the ess

ential planning and training for effectively protecting the workers, the public, and the environment during emergency situations.  Furthermore, the plan is coordinated with the Blue Earth County Emergency Management Director, which includes the local Police department, Sheriff?s Department, Fire Department, and Emergency Medical Service.

In the event of an accidental release, the local Enterprise personnel are trained to sound the emergency notification alarm, shut off the source from a safe location or activate the emergency shutdown system, contact 9-1-1 and secure the area.  The 9-1-1 system is used to notify the Blue Earth County Sheriff?s Department and local Fire Departments.  Remote activation can also be accomplished from the system?s control center which is based in Houston, Texas.  The Enterprise Houston Control Center has area video cameras with dial-up access.  In addition, there are local gas detection systems that alarm locally and in Houston Control.  If these detectors annunciate, the facility can be shutdown remotely from Houston Control or locally by Operation.  A third party contractor, 3E is under contract to effectively contact the necessary agencies if required.  

General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps

Enterprise Products takes a systematic, protective approach to preventing accidental release of hazardous chemicals.  The Process Safety Management systems address each of the key features of successful prevention program, including:

* Process safety information
* Process hazard analysis
* Operating procedures
* Training
* Mechanical integrity
* Management of change
* Pre-Startup Safety Review - "PSSR"
* Compliance audits
* Incident investigation
* Employee participation
* Hot work permit
* Contractors

As a part of the prevention efforts, there are a number of programs in which Enterprise employees participate.  A training program has been developed in which the Operations and Maintenance personn

el are specifically trained in the operation of the facility, the operating procedures, maintenance procedures, and specific other regulations and policies, as well as in all areas of emergency response.  Employees are trained on, use, and apply the guidelines of our PSM program, which include all of the above-listed areas.  All of these programs come under scheduled scrutiny and critique.

There is an on-going inspection program designed to search out and find deficiencies with the process equipment prior to any incident.

The Operations personnel make regular inspections of the equipment and processes they operate.  If something out of the ordinary is found, it is reported to management in order to expediently resolve any problems.

The engineering and administrative controls in place have been established to reduce the risk of an accidental release of identified hazards.  Enterprise Products Operating L.LC. Is committed to operations that are safe for employees and the surrounding community.

Accident History

Records are kept for all significant accidental chemical releases that occur at our facility.  Based on the criteria set forth in 40 CFR 68.10, this facility has not had an accidental release.

Planned Changes to Improve Safety

Facility safety is a primary goal at Enterpirse.  The Mankato Terminal promptly addesses safety recommendations from process hazard analyses conducted at the facility.  Safety management program improvements recommended as a result of internal facility program audits are also acted upon to insure prompt correction.  Safety recommendations made by location employees are considered and implemented if the proposal can be shown to improve facility safety.  The Mankato Terminal safety management (PSM) system is reviewed on a continuing basis with the goal of an improved safety program and a safe facility as a result.  The following is a list of reviews and/or improvements that are planned for implementation at the facility to help preven

t and/or better respond to accidental chemical releases:

* The terminal is planning to relocate the propane pump, add new pump suction valves and modify the propane piping to reduce the amount of flammable material inventory in the terminal piping.
* The terminal is planning to add automatic actuators to the terminal propane block valves to reduce the time needed to stop the flow of propane and isolate the propane pump in response to a possible emergency situation..
